author: Zreddx

text:
Why is the first question people want to know is if something is hard or not? Are you not capable of doing something if it's not easy? So what if coding is difficult or not? Stop being afraid to take challenges people. We as humans always try to find the easiest solution to everything, instead of challenging our minds and making any real effort. No one wants to spend long hours trying to solve a difficult problem. Instead we'd rather have it handed to us or have it put in a way that doesn't take any real effort for us to use our brains to figure out. Stop always wanting to do something that makes you feel safe and secure. Stop doing things that don't leave you room to fail and do something that takes you out of your comfort zone.  So what if you fail, what's stopping you from trying again until you finally find the solution? You run from failure when making mistakes is the only way to get better. 

Instead we take on simple tasks that take no time and almost no willpower to complete and wonder why it's not a long lasting gratification when we complete them, when they didn't even take any real effort to begin with. How can we give someone our best, when we never  gave our best to begin with? Just like the saying  "you are what you eat", you only get what you put in.  You always take on things that don't challenge you, and think you did something but when it's time to put it into practice, you choke. 

Is coding for you? Instead of asking is coding hard, I think the real questions you should ask yourself are:
Are you afraid of problem solving? Are you afraid of challenging the way people think? Do you put your  best foot forward to be the best you can be to not be average? Do you have a creative mind and think outside the box? If you answered no to any of these, then I think you've already found your answer.  Nothing great ever came by taking it easy all the time.﻿

author: Edward Parra

text: No. It's not hard. It's a bit like learning a new language. (The kind that you speak. lol) The thing that gets people is actual programming; trying to understand how to think about how a program functions. Why does this happen? How do you fix it or even just simply get around it? Learning just the basics of how software works in-depth really helps you get started. Find different resources. Try to understand why this works. Practice. You need to practice something if you want to get better at it. Just like everything else in the world. What's also interesting, believe it or not, it you can aid you in other situations besides just programming because you know how to look at something from a different perspective and think, "Why did this happen? Oh. Okay. I understand." You know how to problem solve. That's really the majority of computer programming. Problem solving.﻿

author: Red

text:
It takes a long time to learn to code, you don't learn it overnight. It becomes easy once you have gotten the hang of basic concepts like data types, loops, conditions and variables. 

As for me, my best languages are probably SQL and PHP. I started learning HTML and JavaScript in my fifth year of high school. I dropped out of high school when I was 16 and went to college. I didn't see any point in tormenting myself with another year of school not taking subjects I was really interested in. I decided it was time to go, so off I went.

Coding is a great skill to have, but my main focus is now on security. We need security professionals as much as we need coders. Threats are emerging practically every day. So I am really getting into security. It's where I want to be. I recommend checking out penetration testing to those who want to get into ethical hacking.﻿

author: Anuj Falcon

text:
let's see...bill gates for at least 6 years was known for working near 24 hour days, sometimes leaving to go see a movie and then return to work
zuckerberg is not much different still to this day
and not everyone can be a coder...it's like saying that because you can do math, you'll be able to write something like e=mc2 . theoretically, yes, but day to day, probably not. assuming you don't ever experience feature creep (you will, unless you master project management), then you're looking at long, long days. they don't make those offices with decked out perks for no reason. they want you to stay well into the night. one boss of mine some years back gave us adderall just so we would stay and code just a bit longer. and this is prevalant with many in tech i talk to as well. 
so if you want zero work-life balance, 12-18 hour work days, irrationally paced deadlines, and extreme pressure for absolute perfection, sure, everyone can code.
my only advice is that tech happens to take a lot of the people building it right now (ironically, most jobs are data related and automation, so we are coding ourselves right out of our jobs) and it may be that if you choose this profession you may end up just as miserable and burned out as most coders are. my rule now is if I don't love the project, i just turn it down. do i want the money? of course, everyone does, but i can't stress enough, as someone who has spent most of their youth coding now, make sure you make time for life because it will pass you by faster than any deadline will.﻿

author: TheSam

text:
If you're a person who classifies coding as "easy" I challenge you to browse through the problem set of any popular coding competition. These problems are much more illustrative of the real-world problem solving that is required to write meaningful code. Even most of the problems in the early rounds will NOT be accessible to people who haven't developed their problem-solving abilities. The later rounds will dumbfound the vast majority of people who attempt their problems.

If you want to understand what an actual coding problem looks like, check out google's list of contest problem sets: https://code.google.com/codejam/past-contests

Just click the "problems" link for any of the rounds.﻿

author: What1000HoursOfMemesLooksLike

text:
Hi random person scrolling through the comments,
I just wanted to write this comment to tell you how to ACTUALLY learn how to code/program/develop/whatever. I am going to try to stay away from sounding like someone on /r/iamverysmart but the premise of programming/coding/etc kind of lends itself to be in that realm because of the nature of it. Anyway, I've taken every computer science/programming/etc course offered at my previous high school and I am currently studying software development/general programming in college and I work for a tech startup where I live. What got me first started on this world was playing "Powder Game" as a little kid, and thinking about the behind-the-scenes of how it worked. My dad introduced me to codeacademy, which I took a few basic courses on but never really fully got into it. That is the problem with sites like codingdojo or treehouse or codeacademy or Udemy or whatever other sites that have those Youtube ads of some random 20-something year old that "learned programming/coding after X months" - those sites don't actually teach you very much, at least, they didn't teach ME very much. The way I really got into coding was in high school when I took Pre-AP computer science freshman year. The class started me off in a really simple environment called "Scratch" that used drag-and-drop code to do certain functions. This really helped me get started because it taught me the basics of how code and functions work and work together. It also teaches the basics of variables and things like that. After scratch, the class transitioned into a basic language called VisualBasic and we used software called VisualStudio by Microsoft. This was a good software because it taught me about properties and really offered a good, comprehensive, but still basic enough to grasp coding environment. Next year, I took AP Computer Science A and this class started off with VisualStudio as well, but more advanced aspects of it. Later, we transitioned into NetBeans which is a development environment to learn Java. I would personally recommend starting with Java because a lot of languages build off Java like JavaScript and C#. Java is used for application development and the other two that I mentioned are used for game development primarily. After learning Java (For Loops, nested loops, if loops, while loops, recursion, arrays and 2D arrays) I chose to take Mobile app development and Principles of computer science AP the next year (Principles was a new class that year, I probably would have taken it freshman year otherwise). In Principles, I still learned a ton because the class was more heavily focused on how networking, cyphers, scamming and hacking, and other aspects of computers and networking, like packaging and IP's, IPV4 and IPV6 and such. This class was still incredibly beneficial. Mobile app development didn't teach much because the teacher was trash, but I did end up learning HTML (for those of you that don't know, HTML is used for making websites) because the teacher had us take a codeacademy class for it.

After all of this, I went into animation and graphic design the next year because I had already taken every offered computer programming course. By the time I was a senior, I knew Java fluently and due to outside of class work on games in Unity I learned C# and Javascript fluently. I also knew HTML but only enough to make a really basic website. I personally preferred to make games and applications over websites so I was content. I moved into college after this and took high-level programming courses and software development courses that mainly talked about advanced mathematical computing and computational theory like quantum computing instead of basic coding stuff, but in my software engineering/development classes I did a lot more strict code and cloud-based software development and even got to work on AI development.

I work in the tech startup right now because there was a job fair thing at my college and I talked to them and got hired eventually.

So, that's my story. Hopefully it helps you ACTUALLY learn how to code instead of this BS in the comments and the video above.

For takeaway, I suggest you determine the coding type (websites, game/application design/etc) that you most prefer, then find a language that suits that path best (quick note: if you like AI I suggest Java, though others will say differently). Also, if you haven't already missed your chance, TAKE CLASSES IN HIGH SCHOOL, it stimulates your coding skill and forces you to code weekly. (If your school offers it I also suggest taking OnRamps Statistics because it integrates coding into statistics).

Anyway, I hope I helped. There are two kinds of computer programmers/coders, those who know a little bit of code theory and are asshats to you and pretend like they know everything and are kind of elite (this makes up like 85% of the community) and those who genuinely want to help you learn how to program, because they recognize the importance of it, like Mark Zuckerberg and such)

and one last note, also try to find the IDE (Integrated Development Environment, like Netbeans or VIsualStudio mentioned above) that suits your path best. For me it is Unreal Engine and unity 5+﻿

text: Reading many of the comments below it seems that people look at programming more as a profession rather than simply a skill. Software developing / engineering is the profession, programming a small part of that profession but it’s a skill that can be a standalone skill to anyone in the world and a very highly recommended one at that. Say you own a small business and want to create a small internal application to track your invoices... you can buy a software package that your company may or may not have the funds to do or you can sit down for 4 hours with a skill you learned in high school or college and create your own. Just the point of view of a software engineer.﻿

author: Yi-hsiu Li

text:
Pro's: Creative, rewarding, focused, useful to the company, can remove yourself from a lot of office politics, pride in your work, good salary for full time work, very good salary for contract work.

Con's: Years of training, constant re-education/re-certification, business considers you a cost center, threat of being outsourced or a project being cancelled, unrealistic deadlines, unhealthy (sedentary), unbalanced predominantly male environment, work/life imbalance.

Bottom line: Programming is a fine profession which comes with it's risks and rewards. Do it because you're passionate about programming, don't do it for the money or because you're unsure and just need to choose something - because that's not going to get you through all the training and the tough times.﻿

author: Cliff Newton

text:
9 years ago when i was in highschool, i took Visual Basic. And the reason why i took Visual Basic because i saw a flier on the wall saying "you want to create the next call of duty." I think it was a java class and i spoke to the teacher there and he showed me a book of Java. I think it was Java or C++. idk. But whatever i saw in that book confused me. So he suggested Visual Basics and so i did. 

And visual basic was really tough for me. 

I am not sure but i think even when my teacher first was solving a problem right in front of me, i don't think i had the idea on what coding was. And coding is basically lines of commands that a computer understands so you can solve a problem. I don't think i even understand that. I think even when my teacher was writing codes in front of me on that particular day, it never crossed my mind that i had to use codes. In other words, i was really clueless. I remember he was using the word "dime" because the assignment was on coins. And i believe that "dime" was something you have to use over and over again. I'm not sure. maybe i'm bullshitting this memory since i don't really remember. 

I do have to say tho that completing an assignment felt satisfying. And that is what i liked about coding. I didn't take it in college but tbh, as a 26 year old, i should go back and learn coding again. It is fun and rewarding. 

I remember my teacher in visual basics would always tell me that a computer only know two things, 0 and 1.﻿

author: himanshu khattar

text:
Coding is difficult. It takes a lot of practice. But eventually you'll get it, so just hang in there and keep working at it. That's what I would say.

I think that it's not a good idea from an educational point of view to tell the people you're about to teach something that it's not difficult. Because that means you're setting an expectation of easy progress and little struggle. Instead, you should be setting an expectation that students will struggle quite a lot before they grasp the concepts and that it's only easy once you get used to it. That encourages you to go through with the problems, even when they appear impossible to solve at first, and keep practicing until indeed you are comfortable with the materials. Telling someone what they are doing is easy is effectively saying "if you struggle with it then you're an idiot because it's easy, and if you don't struggle with it you've hardly achieved anything because it's easy".﻿
author: Ralph Schraven

text: Programming isn't hard, but teaching programming is. As a PhD student I have teaching duties and had to give six lectures on basic programming in Matlab (I don't think that what language matter since most have the same basic concepts but with different syntax). Before I did that I thought that everyone could learn programming but now I have seen that some have a hard time to even understand that the content of a variable can be changed, or how to use a if statement. As one said in the video, learning how to program is like learning how to play an instrument, and anyone who have tried to learn an instrument knows that even the best have to practice every day which needs dedication.﻿

author: P Weme

text:
yea Coding Is Not Difficult.
because Coding is nothing but typing out lines of locally functional code ...

Software Engineering, on the other hand, is endlessly complex, with every design decision having drastic tradeoffs for what your software will be like to debug and maintain and enhance and refactor and port and extend and collaborate upon.  For a Software Engineer, every line of code has nuance and every block of code has nuance.  Just because you can't see and understand the nuance, doesn't mean that it's not there ... you just lack a deep understanding of what it is you're building (or rather, what it is you should be engineering).

If all you're interested in doing is Coding, then please DON'T go work at any of the companies that produce the software that I depend on in my daily life.

Don't go work at Apple.
Don't go work at YouTube.
Don't go work at Google.
Don't go work at Facebook.
Don't go work at Yahoo!.
Don't go work at CNN.
Don't go work at Redbox.

Unless, of course, you're striving to be a Software Engineer instead of only a Coder.﻿

text:
Writing code is one thing.
Being able to problem solve, and utilize your knowledge of code is completely different.

An individual can know to use a hammer. A drill. Flashlight. All necessary building tools. This does not mean they can ever create a large mansion.﻿

author: Mikkel Petersen

text:
Mikkel Petersen whatever you need to believe in order to convince yourself that buying a Mac isn't just about following a trend that was created through good marketing and crappy business practices alone. Let me tell you a story anyone with Google can easily verify : if you have a powerful GPU on your Windows PC, you can't use it as a hardware accelerator in some famous video editing software I won't name. But if you use the same GPU on a Mac, then it works. The only difference is in the software's GPU plugins, and that difference is an arbitrary setting that favors Macs over PC's. This has led to people coming up with the "hackintosh" method, where you install MacOS on a PC by tricking it into thinking it's Apple hardware. Then you can use your GPU to its full extent on video editing. And everyone I know who's built a hackintosh from a PC ended-up with a Mac that outperformed Apple machines easily twice as expensive.

So, to recap, an arbitrary limitation in software is the basis on which some people claim Macs are better than PC's for video editing and therefore worth the huge price tag. Meanwhile, I challenge you to name a single engineering or scientific institution anywhere on Earth that uses Macs.﻿

text: Coding is not all that easy if you want to do it well.  Over my career I've met so many bad coders.  In fact, I would say it is extremely difficult at the highest level. Bill Gates knows that he is wrong when he says all it takes "adding and subtracting."  Some of the still unanswered problems in mathematics are in computation.﻿

text: I love being a developer but there is this big myth in today's fiction and that myth is fueled by the press that you can become a billionaire by being an innovative developer. Well there is no rule that you can't. But you usually become a billionaire by being a successful businessman and of course learning code will help make a successful business. Don't get me wrong developer jobs can be very well paid but the myth of the successful coder who becomes a rich spoiled kid is very useful to attract potential recruits. Gates didn't become a billionnaire because he was a coding genius but because he bought DOS from another company and successfully marketed. Windows was then coded by a team not by a nerd in a garage. Maybe it reflected his amazing innovative vision of the future but he didnt become rich by typing lines of code. The same thing can be said of Facebook it was very well marketed. There were other solutions on the market that looked more interesting on paper when FB came out. Not saying FB is not at the cutting edge of web development but it has never really been a technical revolution. Sometimes it happened though.The guys who made Doom started by making games in their garage or more recently Notch the guy behind Minecraft. This said Notch wasn't the best programmer in the world but he managed to make a unique and popular game all by himself. And yeah the bottom line is those guy become billionnaires but there are usually not the guys making the code. But unless you learn coding you'll never know if you are the next guy who is going to find the idea that makes the bucks, or the guy who gets his idea stolen by the guy who makes the bucks :D﻿

author: Ruslan Mashinov

text:
In general, yes.  Intellectually, no. Not by a long shot.  

Programming is super hard!  You are always learning new things and as you get older, it gets harder to learn new skills and information and retain them . You need to be an excellent problem solver.  Most of your work will involve finding out why something is not doing what you want it to do. Everyday there is a new problem and even if you specialize in a certain area, technology will always change or new challenges will surface.  That's just the programming part.  You need to know about the domain, or what problem your program is trying to solve.  It could be literally anything,  If you're writing software for accountants, for instance,, you better know about accounting too.  If your writing a CAD module, you better know the math and the internals of the program the module will interface with.  Most programmers work in teams not to shorten the development time, but to spread out the cognitive load.

Doctors only have to know about their specialty and will often refer patients to other specialists. Most of the stuff they learn in medical school is useless on the job.  Diagnosing conditions is easy  You follow a flow chart and you better follow it.  If you don't you might not get paid by the insurer, or worse, sued if it goes bad.  Having good intuition and problem solving skills isn't much of an advantage.﻿

text: Problem with assembler as opposed to say c, is each IC chip has a different instruction set / architecture with different assembler code. With C you can move the same piece of code over to different chips with the same outcome. Assembler is a low level programming language. If you want to learn the inner workings of the hardware /chip assembler is the way to go, however it's very tedious; multiple  lines of code to move a byte of code over to a different register. With C this can be done with a single line of code.﻿

author: Ruslan Mashinov

text: Very different things. Its not used to show a skill level, or anything like that, it's just 2 completely different concepts. A site like code.org telling you exactly what to write, and you writing it, is coding. Using knowledge to solve a problem using code is programming. No sane person calls themselves a "professional programmer" while calling others "professional coders". They probably are just using the words interchangeably.﻿

author: PerfectorZY

text:
That OneGuy, no one ever learns "all of coding." You'd be lucky to get to a professional level of programming in one/two languages in under two years. I know everyone says "you can learn in six months, 3 months," but it's honestly not enough time to have key concepts sink in and practice. 

Learn Java, C#, JavaScript, SQL, and  HTML/CSS. Python if you have the time. If you can only learn one, learn Java, or at least have this be your first language. 

But, first, learn how to solve problems like a programmer, then the languages just become your toolbox.﻿

text:
I taught myself, and my first program just printed something to the console. That's generally the simplest thing in any programming language, off of the top of my head there's QBasic: "PRINT "HELLO"" there's python: "print 'hello'" there's c#: "Console.Writeline("Hello"); and so on, it's a just a one line thing that's usually built into the language or IDE you use.

I would imagine it's pretty rare to start off on anything else, usually graphics rendering is one of the more complex things in a language (the only language that had it simple was QBasic, and it probably wouldn't be the first thing you find when learning)﻿

author: asmcriminaL

text:
First of all the title is a bit misleading. In this comment section alone I see the words "coder" and "programmer" intertwined as if they referred to the same thing. They do not.

I am a retired programmer myself. I have a degree in Computer Hardware Architecture, one in Advanced Programming and one in Graphic Arts. I was originally going to work for Intel but as faith had it I met with a top developer and they paid for both the Programming and Graphic Arts degrees while I worked for them and climbed their ladder. 

Back to the original comment. 
A Coder knows how to write in the given programming language but they generally need some kind of guidance or instruction or supervision to do so. They are normally given tasks to do. Some kind of requested goal.

A programmer on the other hand needs no supervision and brainstorms the logic and problem solving way before inputting 1 line of code. This takes many years of experience and further education to do so. It is a discipline.

Developers (at least those I have worked with) tend to take their advice on what should be implemented in the software or what should be done from the programmer whereas with coders they are told what needs to be done.

Those who spoke in this video are not ALL programmers. Coders yes. Programmers no. They got their breaks because they mostly were from wealthy families and they had connections in the business world and with promotions. This is a luxury not everyone has. I do yes but not always and certainly not when I worked 2 jobs and went to college full time.﻿
